7z (.7z), ACE (.ace), ALZIP (.alz), AR (.a), ARC (.arc), ARJ (.arj), BZIP2 (.bz2), CAB (.cab), compress (.Z), CPIO (.cpio), DEB (.deb), DMS (.dms), GZIP (.gz), LRZIP (.lrz), LZH (.lha, .lzh), LZIP (.lz), LZMA (.lzma), LZOP (.lzo), RPM (.rpm), RAR (.rar), RZIP (.rz), TAR (.tar), XZ (.xz), ZIP (.zip, .jar) and ZOO (.zoo)
automation.name: UnPackFile

automation.description:
Extraction of all matches from a specified regular expression pattern from a provided string.  Returns an array of results.  This differs from RegexGroups in several ways:

* It returns all matches of the specified pattern, not just specific groups.  This is useful for extracting things using a pattern where the content of the source string is indeterminate, such as extracting all email addresses.
* Some "convenience" arguments have been added to enhance usability: multi-line, ignore_case, period_matches_newline
* Added a new argument, "error_if_no_match".  The script will not ordinarily throw an error if a match is not found but if not using as a transformer within a playbook, it may, in certain limited circumstances, be desirable to throw an error if the expression doesn't match.
* It uses the 'regex'  library, which supports more some more advanced regex functionality than the standard 're' library.  For more info, see https://pypi.org/project/regex/.
automation.name: RegexExtractAll

automation.description: Check if an email address's domain is trying to squat other domain using Levenshtein distance algorithm

In order to run successfully, the script should be configured to trigger on SLA breach, through field edit mode.

automation.description:
This script converts the input value into another value using two lists. The input value is searched in the first list (input_values). 
If it exists, the value from the second list (mapped_values) at the same index is retutrned. If there is no match, the original value is returned.
If the original input is a dictionary, then the script will look for a "stringified" version of the key/:/value pair in the input_values and then map the result in the output_values into the original "value".

Example 1:

input_values = "1,2,3,4"
mapper_values = "4,3,2,1"
value = 3

Output would be "2"

Example 2:

input_values ="firstkey: datahere,secondkey: datathere"
mapper_values = "datathere,datahere"
value(dict)= {
                                "firstkey": "datahere"
                          }

Output would be:
                          {
                                "firstkey": "datathere"
                           }

The reason for matching the key AND value pair in a dictionary is to allow the mappig of values that have a specific key name. In most cases, dictionaries will continan key-value pairs in which the values are the same. You might want to change the value of KeyA, but not the value of KeyB. This method gives control over which key is changed.

When the input is a dict, str , int, or list, the output is ALWAYS returned as a string.
automation.name: MapValuesTransformer

automation.name: URLReputation

E.g. !WhereFieldEquals with the following arguments:
 - value=[{ "name": "192.1,0.82", "type": "IP" }, { "name": "myFile.txt", "type": "File" }, { "name": "172.0.0.2", "type": "IP" }]
 - field='type'
 - equalTo='IP'
 - getField='name' 

Will return all items names where field 'type' equals 'IP' - ['192.1,0.82', '172.0.0.2']

automation.name: ConvertFile

automation.description:
Find tables inside HTML and extract the contents into objects using the following logic:
- If table has a single column, just create an array of strings from the values
- If table has 2 columns and has no header row, treat the first column as key and second as value and create a table of key/value
- If table has a header row, create a table of objects where attribute names are the headers
- If table does not have a header row, create table of objects where attribute names are cell1, cell2, cell3...
automation.name: ExtractHTMLTables

automation.description:
Assign analyst to incident.
By default,  the analyst is picked randomly from the available users, according to the provided roles (if no roles provided, will fetch all users).
Otherwise, the analyst will be picked according to the 'assignBy' arguments.
machine-learning: DBot will calculated and decide who is the best analyst for the job.
top-user: The user that is most commonly owns this type of incident
less-busy-user: The less busy analyst will be picked to be the incident owner.
online: The analyst is picked randomly from all online analysts, according to the provided roles (if no roles provided, will fetch all users).
current: The user that executed the command
automation.name: AssignAnalystToIncident

automation.description: Returns the first element of an array.  If the value passed is not an array, it returns the original value that was passed.
automation.name: FirstArrayElement

automation.description:
Pretty-print data using Python's pprint library.  This is useful for seeing the structure of incident and context data.  Here's how to use it:

!PrettyPrint value=${incident}
automation.name: PrettyPrint

automation.description: After running DeleteContext, this script can repopulate all the file entries in the ${File} context key
automation.name: RepopulateFiles

automation.description: This script adds the reputation to Onion URL indicators. The script is automatically triggered when a Onion URL indicator is auto-extracted. For instance, if you run a Cortex XSOAR CLI on a valid Onion URL, the indicators are extracted automatically and this script is triggered for the extracted indicators.
automation.name: OnionURLReputation

automation.description: Allows to parse and extract http flows (requests & responses) from a pcap/pcapng file.
automation.name: PcapHTTPExtractor

automation.description: A context script for IP entities
automation.name: IPReputation

automation.name: CompareIncidentsLabels

automation.name: VerifyIPv6Indicator

automation.description: Count an array size
automation.name: CountArraySize

automation.description: Returns a map entry with marker on the given coordinate (lat, lng).
automation.name: ShowOnMap

automation.description: Widget script to view information about the relationship between an indicator, entity and other indicators and connect to indicators, if relevant.
automation.name: FeedRelatedIndicatorsWidget

automation.description: This is a thin wrapper around the `dateutil.parser.parse` function. It will parse a string containing a date/time stamp and return it in ISO 8601 format.
automation.name: DateStringToISOFormat

automation.description: Parses a CSV and looks for a specific value in a specific column, returning a dict of the entire matching row. If no column value is specified, the entire CSV is read into the context.

automation.name: ExtractFQDNFromUrlAndEmail
CreateEmailHtmlBody

Converts
https:%2F%2Fexample.com
into

automation.description:
Extract indicators from a text-based file.
Indicators that can be extracted:
* IP
* Domain
* URL
* File Hash
* Email Address
automation.name: ExtractIndicatorsFromTextFile

automation.description: Resolve the original URL from the given shortened URL and place it in both as output and in the context of a playbook. (https://unshorten.me/api)
automation.name: ResolveShortenedURL

automation.description:
This function generates a password and allows various parameters to customize the properties of the password depending on the use case (e.g. password complexity requirements).  The default behavior is to generate a password of  *random length* including all four character classes (upper, lower, digits, symbols) with at least five and at most ten characters per class. 

The min_* values all default to 0. This means that if the command is executed in this way:
!GeneratePassword max_lcase=10
It is possible that a password of length zero could be generated. It is therefore recommended to always include a min_* parameter that matches. 

The debug parameter will print certain properties of the command into the WarRoom for easy diagnostics.
automation.name: GeneratePassword

automation.description: Converts XML string to JSON format
automation.name: ConvertXmlToJson

automation.description: Add a remote system (such as a desktop under investigation) to an investigation (this will allow you to install and agent on the system)
automation.name: IncidentAddSystem

automation.description: Calculates the entropy for the given data.
automation.name: CalculateEntropy

automation.description: Decodes an input in Base64 format.
automation.name: Base64Decode

automation.description: Expose the incident owner into IncidentOwner context key
automation.name: ExposeIncidentOwner

automation.description:
Gather information regarding CIDR -
    1. Broadcast_address
    2. CIDR
    3. First_address
    4. Last address
    5. Max prefix len
    6. Num addresses
    7. Private
    8. Version
automation.name: IPNetwork

automation.description: Parse an email from an eml or msg file and populate all relevant context data to investigate the email. Also extracts inner attachments and returns them to the war room. The incident labels themselves are preserved and not modified - only the "Label/x" context items that originated from the labels, and the best practice is to rely on these for the remainder of the playbook.
automation.name: ParseEmailFiles

automation.description: Check if a given value exists in the context. Will return 'no' for empty empty arrays. To be used mostly with DQ and selectors.
automation.name: Exists

automation.description:
The script receives a list of fields and a context key base path. For example, Key=demisto.result List=username,user and will get all of the values from demisto.result.username and demisto.result.user.
The Get field of the task must have the value ${.=[]}.
automation.name: GetValuesOfMultipleFields

automation.description:
Set indicator reputation to "suspicious" when malicious ratio is above threshold.
Malicious ratio is the ration between number of "bad" incidents to total number of incidents the indicator appears in.
automation.name: MaliciousRatioReputation

automation.description: Compares a single timestamp to a list of timestamps.
automation.name: TimeStampCompare

automation.description: Gets all IP addresses in context, excluding ones given.
automation.name: ContextGetIps

automation.description: Returns a dict of all incident fields that exist in the system.
automation.name: IncidentFields

automation.description: Takes a date or time input and adds or subtracts a determined amount of time. Returns a string in date or time in ISO Format.
automation.name: ModifyDateTime

automation.description: Called by the GenericPolling playbook, schedules the polling task.
automation.name: ScheduleGenericPolling

automation.description: Checks if the Docker container running this script has been hardened according to the recommended settings at: https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xsoar/6-0/cortex-xsoar-admin/docker/docker-hardening-guide.html
automation.name: DockerHardeningCheck

automation.description: Accepts an array of domains as a blacklist, and a list of email addresses. The script then filters out any email address whose domain is in the blacklist.  The filtered list will be returned as an array.
automation.name: EmailDomainBlacklist

automation.description: Checks if the investigation found any malicious indicators (file, URL, IP address, domain, or email). Returns "yes" if at least one malicious indicator is found.
automation.name: IsMaliciousIndicatorFound

automation.description: Utility script to use in playbooks - returns "yes" if the input is non-empty.
automation.name: UtilAnyResults

automation.description: Executes a test for all integration instances available and returns detailed information about succeeded and failed integration instances.
automation.name: FailedInstances

automation.description: Execute a command on a remote machine (without installing a D2 agent)
automation.name: RemoteExec

automation.description: Add into the incident's context the system internal DBot score for the input indicator
automation.name: GetIndicatorDBotScore

automation.description: Converts a custom-formatted timestamp to UNIX epoch time. Use it to convert custom time stamps to a Demisto date field.  Uses the python strptime format.  For more info, see: https://docs.python.org/3.7/library/datetime.html#strftime-and-strptime-behavior
automation.name: FormattedDateToEpoch

automation.description: This script accepts multiple values for both arguments and will iterate through each of the domains to check if the specified subdomains are located in at least one of the specified main domains. If the tested subdomain is in one of the main domains, the result will be true. For example, if the domain_to_check values are apps.paloaltonetworks.com and apps.paloaltonetworks.bla and the domains_to_compare values are paloaltonetworks.com and demisto.com, the result for apps.paloaltonetworks.com will be true since it is a part of the paloaltonetworks.com domain. The result for apps.paloaltonetworks.bla will be false since it is not a part of the paloaltonetworks.com or demisto.com domain.
automation.name: IsInternalDomainName

automation.description: Calculate the time difference, in minutes
automation.name: CalculateTimeDifference

automation.description: Encode a file as base64 and store it in a Demisto list.
automation.name: FileToBase64List

Used to extract indicators from Word files (DOC, DOCX).

Replaces regex match/es in string.
